history.content:
The courses are fairly different I think. 172 is about complexity theory while 276 is about crypto. I think the only prereq for 276 is 170 according to the fall 2014 website (and since Garg is teaching again that should still hold).

----------------------------------------

172 covers a strict subset of Sipser's book. When Luca taught it we didn't cover things like context free grammars and push down automata and such, but went more in depth into modern-ish complexity theory (like zero knowledge proofs and the PCP theorem and a bit of hardness of approximation).

Wrt the relation b/w 276 and 172, the above student answer is a bit misleading, since modern theoretical crypto has its foundations in complexity theory.

So having the basics of that down helps a lot in keeping up with Sanjam's version of class, which assumes familiarity with Turing machines and reductions. When Sanjam last taught it he covered a number of topics, so having familiarity with the basics is highly recommended.

The courses are fairly different I think. 172 is about complexity theory while 276 is about crypto. I think the only prereq for 276 is 170 according to the fall 2014 website (and since Garg is teaching again that should still hold).
The courses are fairly different I think. 172 is about complexity theory while 276 is about crypto. I think the only prereq for 276 is 170 according to the fall 2014 website.

I want to take CS276 this fall. I was recommended to review Sipser's Theory of Computation this summer. If I do the entire book and the problems on the 172 course page, have I mostly covered the course material, such that taking the actual class would be redundant?

As an aside, I'm looking for more theory courses. I'm taking 170 this semester. Is 174 good? I'm really interested in taking 270, which hopefully I can do next spring. I'm also interested in 271 Randomness, 274 Geometry, and 278 Complexity, but they don't seem to be offered often (none of them have a slot on the draft schedule for all of next year). Would they be offered two years from now?
history.subject: Self-studying CS172, questions about theory courses
